author: Leo Schlink in London
title: Wimbledon 2015: Andy Murray to face Roger Federer in semi-final | The
text:
ROGER Federer and Andy Murray have charged into a blockbuster Wimbledon confrontation with straight sets victories on a day marred by rain and overzealous officiating.
Federer set a stellar standard by sweeping into 10th All England Club semi-final with a supreme grass court demolition of Frenchman Gilles Simon.
The world No. 2 strolled into the last four with a rain-interrupted 6-3 7-5 6-2 win over 12th seed Simon.
And Murray was just as ruthless with a measured 6-4 7-5 6-4 victory over Canadian Vasek Pospisil, who was twice penalised for time-wasting.
At 33, Federer earned a record 37th grand slam semi-final appearance with 11 aces and 36 winners.
Roger Federer has earned his 37th grand slam semi appearance. Source: AFP
Andy Murray will contest his 17th major semi. Source: Getty Images
Murray will contest his 17th major semi and sixth at Wimbledon after nudging four aces and 23 winners past Pospisil.
Watched by Rod Laver, Federer’s wonderful serving was the foundation of his 78th Wimbledon win from 87 matches, conceding only 11 points on his first delivery for the match.
His sole double fault came on match point. Almost embarrassed, the Swiss maestro surged menacingly to the net on the following point to clinch victory with a slashing volley.
Federer said two rain delays worked in his favour.
“It’s never easy for either player, plus it was quite windy out there,” the grand slam record-holder said.
“The stop and goes are not easy for either player. I think the breaks actually helped rather than hindered me. I was able to stay in front and reset well.”
Switzerland's Roger Federer same the rain worked in his favour. Source: AFP
Murray said the scoreline belied the closeness of the contest.
“I felt I like I played some good stuff, he served extremely well for patches. It was extremely tough out there,” he said.
“I changed my return position a few times to help myself and make him think about it a little bit. It was difficult with the rain delays. I hope I can get to another final, but it will be tough.”
Federer had not lost to Simon since 2008, winning five straight matches — and there was no danger of the sequence ending on Wimbledon grass.
Roger Federer has not lost to Gilles Simon since 2008. Source: AFP
Shoved out to Court One to accommodate Murray on centre court, Federer was the epitome of ruthless efficiency.
He broke serve in the second game and led 3-0 before a 36-minute rain delay halted his progress.
When play resumed, Federer calmly picked up where he left off, methodically dissecting Simon’s innocuous game.
As bravely as Simon strove, he simply did not have the weaponry to trouble Federer.
The Swiss suffered a rare concentration lapse at 5-4 when serving for the set. Bradley Cooper and Mirka Federer take in Roger Federer’s battle at Wimbledon. Source: Getty Images
Remarkably it was Federer’s first dropped serve in 116 games, stretching back to the first round of Halle last month. He quickly redeemed himself in the following game and was serving for the set a second time, only to foiled by the return of the rain.
Needing only three points to move to a two sets to love gap, Federer moved in for the kill by breaking Simon’s delivery in the third game of the third set.
Sensing Simon’s waning spirit, Federer broke again in the seventh game before securing victory after 95 minutes.
Watched by Prince William and Princess Kate, David Beckham and assorted tennis royalty, Murray jumped to a 3-1 lead after Pospisil blundered on serve in the third game.
The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and Bear Grylls cheer on Andy Murray. Source: Getty Images
The Scot pounced to have early momentum before officials were caught out for leaving centre court roof open despite forecasts of rain.
The decision cost 36 minutes were lost before Murray closed out the set in heavy, blustery conditions.
Reading his notebook at the changeovers, Pospisil began to find range as the contest intensified.
The tall baseliner continued to build pressure before rain again intervened, falling onto an unprotected court under an unused roof.
After waiting 35 minutes to resume, Murray chipped away at Pospisil’s resilience and was rewarded with a vital break for 6-5. Andy Murray of Great Britain plays a backhand against Vasek Pospisil of Canada. Source: Getty Images
Warned by French umpire Pascal Maria for taking too much time between serves, Pospisil suddenly trailed by two sets.
Incredibly, after being back on court for only five games, the Canadian asked for — and was granted — a toilet break.
Pospisil earned another time wasting violation in the eighth game and was stripped of a first serve for the offence.
Maria’s officiating was not well received — even by a fiercely partisan Murray crowd, who jeered the umpire.
Federer holds a 12-11 edge in head-to-head matches with Murray. Andy Murray was too much for Vasek Pospisil. Source: AFP
